instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PM_PCH_PWROK: What is PM_PCH_PWROK? PM_PCH_PWROK is usually created by U1950, a 74LVC2G08GT chip and is necessary for the machine to wake from an S5 and S4 state and turn on. This signal will be present if ALL_SYS_PWRGD, CPU_VR_PGOOD, PP3V3_S0, and PP3V42_G3H are present. When this signal is not present or intermittent, usually pin 8 on U1950 for PP3V42_G3H is corroded..

threads.title: 820 2936 - don't Show image
threads.message:
Hey, 

This machine does not show image. I think it should be because a peak off current in E - NET CONN.

<TRANSISTOR>Q4262</TRANSISTOR> heats up and i replaced. Next, <CHIP>U2150</CHIP> heat too and replaced!  After that the components doesn't heat anymore! But don't have any image... 

an help? thank you??

threads.title: 820 2936 - don't Show image
threads.message: Chimes? <CHIP>U2150</CHIP> does not exist on 2936 board.

threads.title: 820 2936 - don't Show image
threads.message:
Don't chimes! and without rams no beep's.. Processor heats up! This board came for another store...

the component i was talking about is: [url]https://drive.google.com/file/d/1TY0XF84VwgzoLvqF0P4wofdusD_jQKyJ/view?usp=sharing[/url]

threads.title: 820 2936 - don't Show image
threads.message:
Voltage of <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>?

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> High? <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL> High?

EDIT:
The component you posted is indeed <CHIP>U2150</CHIP> on my board view as well
Since its connected to <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL>, I would not be surprised <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL> is low for you
